continues to explore sublease alternatives with respect to this facility.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
European headquarters in London, England, currently occupy approximately
450,000 square feet of leased office space in the Broadgate complex.&#160; These leases expire at various dates to
2017. Approximately 34,000 square feet have been subleased to an unaffiliated
third party.&#160; In March 2001, the Company
agreed to lease up to 1,000,000 square feet of space in a new tower at the
Canary Wharf development, east of the City of London, with a 30-year term.&#160; The Company expects to relocate to this
facility in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2003 and is exploring sublease options
for the Broadgate space.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2002
the Company entered into a lease with an initial 2-year term for a new
approximately 157,000 square foot Asian headquarters location in the Roppongi
Hills area of central Tokyo, Japan.&#160; The
Company&#146;s current Asian headquarters occupy approximately 100,000 square feet of
leased office space in the ARK Mori Building in central Tokyo.&#160; The ARK Mori lease has been extended to
early 2004 to coincide with the Company&#146;s planned relocation to the Roppongi
Hills building.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All three of the
Company&#146;s business segments (as described herein and in the Consolidated
Financial Statements of the Registrant and its subsidiaries) use the facilities
described above (or will use them, in the case of facilities to be occupied).</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Facilities
occupied by the Company (or to be occupied as described above) are believed to
be adequate for the purposes for which they are (or are to be) used, and the
occupied facilities are well maintained.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Additional
information with respect to facilities, certain charges related thereto and
lease commitments is set forth in Notes&nbsp;2 and 3 and under the caption
&#147;Lease Commitments&#148; in Note 20 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial
Statements in the 2002 Annual Report and is incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font></b>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><a name="Item3_LegalProceedings"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">ITEM 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font></b></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is
involved in a number of judicial, regulatory and arbitration proceedings
concerning matters arising in connection with the conduct of its business. Such
proceedings include actions brought against the Company and others with respect
to transactions in which the Company acted as an underwriter or financial
advisor, actions arising out of the Company&#146;s activities as a broker or dealer
in securities and commodities and actions brought on behalf of various classes
of claimants against many securities and commodities firms, including the
Company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Although there can
be no assurance as to the ultimate outcome, the Company generally has denied,
or believes it has a meritorious defense and will deny, liability in all
significant cases pending against it including the matters described below, and
it intends to defend vigorously each such case.&#160; Based on information currently available and established
reserves, the Company believes that the eventual outcome of the actions against
it, including the matters described below, will not, in the aggregate, have a
material adverse effect on the consolidated financial position or cash flows of
the Company but may be material to the Company&#146;s operating results for any
particular period, depending on the level of the Company&#146;s income for such
period.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Research Analyst Independence
Investigations</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;layout-grid-mode:both;">On December 20, 2002, LBI reached an agreement in
principle with the SEC, the New York State Attorney General&#146;s Office, the New
York Stock Exchange</font> (&#147;NYSE&#148;)</font><font style="layout-grid-mode:both;">, the NASD and the North American Securities
Administrators Association (on behalf of state securities regulators) to
resolve their investigations of the Company relating to allegations of research
analyst conflicts of interest.&#160; Pursuant
to the agreement in principle, LBI agreed, among other things, (i) to pay $50
million in retrospective relief, (ii) to contribute $25 million spread over
five years to provide third-party independent research to clients, (iii) to
contribute $5 million towards investor education and (iv) to adopt internal
structural and operational reforms that will further augment the steps it has
already taken to promote research analyst independence.&#160; The agreement in principle will become final
upon execution of written agreements acceptable to all of the parties and final
judicial approval of the settlement.</font>&#160;
In the fourth quarter of fiscal 2002, the Company recorded a pre-tax
charge associated with the agreement in principle; for additional information
see Note 4&nbsp;of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements in the 2002
Annual Report, which is incorporated herein by reference.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">AIA Holding SA et al. v. Lehman
Brothers Inc. and Bear Stearns &amp; Co., Inc.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In July 1997, LBI
was served with a complaint in the United States District Court for the
Southern District of New York (the &#147;New York District Court&#148;) in which 277
named plaintiffs asserted 24 causes of action against LBI and Bear Stearns
&amp; Co., Inc. The amount of damages was unspecified. The claims arose from
the activities of an individual named Ahmad Daouk, who was employed by an
introducing broker which introduced accounts to LBI between 1988 and 1992.
Daouk allegedly perpetrated a fraud upon the claimants, who are mostly
investors of Middle Eastern origin, and the complaint alleged that LBI breached
various contractual and common law duties owed to the investors.&#160; In March 1998, the District Court dismissed
without prejudice 18 of the 24 counts pleaded in the complaint. In July 1998,
the plaintiffs served a First Amended Complaint containing 18 causes of action
against LBI and/or Bear Stearns.&#160; Prior
to the date for the trial, in December 2002 all parties agreed to a settlement
of all claims.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing:0pt;">Actions Regarding Enron Corporation</font></i></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In April 2002, a
Consolidated Complaint for Violation of the Securities Laws was filed in the
United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas (the &#147;Texas
District Court&#148;) in <i><font style="font-style:italic;">In re Enron Corporation Securities Litigation </font></i>(the &#147;<i><font style="font-style:italic;">Enron Litigation</font></i>&#148;), alleging claims for violation of
Sections 11 and 15 of the Securities Act of 1933 (the &#147;Securities Act&#148;),
Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the &#147;Exchange Act&#146;), and
Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and the Texas Securities Act.&#160; The case is brought purportedly on behalf of purchasers of Enron
Corporation&#146;s publicly traded equity and debt securities between
October&nbsp;19, 1998, and November&nbsp;27, 2001, against Holdings and eight
other commercial or investment banks, 38 current or former Enron officers and
directors, Enron&#146;s accountants, Arthur Andersen LLP (&#147;Andersen&#148;) (and
affiliated entities and partners) and two law firms.&#160; The complaint seeks unspecified compensatory and injunctive
relief based on the theory that defendants engaged or participated in </font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">13</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font></b>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">manipulative devices to
inflate Enron&#146;s reported profits and financial condition, made false or
misleading statements and participated in a scheme or course of business to
defraud Enron&#146;s shareholders.&#160; On
December 20, 2002, the Court granted Holdings&#146; motion to dismiss as to the
Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim and dismissed that claim as to Holdings.&#160; The other claims against Holdings remain
pending.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In May 2002, a
complaint was filed in the District Court of Galveston County, Texas, 56th
Judicial Circuit, against LBI and Holdings by American National Insurance
Company and certain of its affiliates.&#160;
The complaint is based on the allegations in the<i><font style="font-style:italic;"> Enron Litigation</font></i> and asserts that plaintiffs relied on
defendants&#146; allegedly false and misleading statements in purchasing and
continuing to hold Enron debt and equities in their LBI accounts.&#160; The complaint alleges violations of the
Texas State Securities Act, fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, negligence and
professional malpractice, and seeks unspecified compensatory relief and
punitive damages. LBI and Holdings removed this case to the Texas District
Court, and plaintiffs have filed a motion to remand the case back to state
court.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Also in May 2002,
a Third Amended Petition was filed in the District Court of Tulsa County,
Oklahoma, by Samson Investment Company alleging that Andersen is liable for
plaintiffs&#146; damages, allegedly incurred in connection with certain contracts
entered into with Enron.&#160; Plaintiffs
allege that Andersen conspired with Enron to misrepresent Enron&#146;s financial
condition in its financial statements.&#160;
In December 2002, Andersen filed a Third-Party Petition against LBI,
Holdings and other commercial and investment banks.&#160; The Third Party Petition seeks contribution from LBI and Holdings
in the event Andersen is held liable to plaintiffs and alleges that LBI,
Holdings and other third-party defendants were involved in creating and using
Enron&#146;s special purpose entities (&#147;SPEs&#148;), engaged in transactions with the
SPEs, misrepresented or failed to disclose to Andersen information about the
SPEs and issued analysts&#146; reports that enhanced the public&#146;s perception of
Enron&#146;s financial performance and condition.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In August 2002, a
complaint was filed in the Court of Common Pleas, Civil Division, Franklin
County, Ohio, against Holdings, along with four other commercial or investment
banks, among other defendants, by the Public Employees Retirement System of
Ohio and three other state employee retirement plans.&#160; The complaint alleges that defendants engaged or participated in
manipulative devices to inflate Enron&#146;s reported profits and financial
condition, made false or misleading statements and participated in a scheme or
course of business to defraud Enron&#146;s shareholders, and that plaintiffs relied
on defendants&#146; false and misleading statements in purchasing and continuing to
hold Enron debt and equities in the State&#146;s pension funds.&#160; Against Holdings, the complaint alleges
claims for common law fraud and deceit, aiding and abetting common law fraud,
conspiracy to commit fraud, negligent misrepresentation and violation of the
Texas Securities Act, and seeks unspecified compensatory relief and punitive
damages.&#160; This action was removed to
federal court, transferred to the Texas District Court and consolidated with
the <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Enron
Litigation</font></i>.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Also in August
2002, Capital Management, L.P., the former general partner of LJM2
Co-Investment, L.P. (&#147;LJM2&#148;), an Enron-related SPE, filed a third-party claim
in Delaware Chancery Court alleging that Holdings&#146; subsidiary LB&nbsp;I Group
Inc., an investor in LJM2, together with the other LJM2 limited partners
breached the Limited Partnership Agreement by rescinding a capital call.&#160; The case has been removed to federal court
and a motion has been made to transfer it to the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in
Dallas, Texas, where the LJM2 bankruptcy is proceeding.&#160; A motion to remand the case back to state
court is also pending.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In
September&nbsp;2002, the Washington State Investment Board, which is a named
plaintiff in the <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Enron Litigation</font></i>, filed a new purported class action in the
Texas District Court.&#160; This action
mirrors the claims in the <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Enron Litigation</font></i>, but alleges a class
action period of September&nbsp;9, 1997, to October&nbsp;18, 1998.&#160; This action is an attempt to expand the
class action period in the <i><font style="font-style:italic;">Enron Litigation</font></i> based upon the lengthened
statute of limitations in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In October 2002,
two actions were filed in Iowa state court (Linn and Polk Counties) against LBI
and Holdings, along with several other commercial or investment banks, by AUSA
Life Insurance Co., Principal Global Investors, LLC, and certain other
purchasers of Enron securities.&#160; The
complaints seek rescission and an unspecified amount of compensatory and punitive
damages.&#160; The complaints allege that
defendants participated in the alleged Enron fraudulent scheme by participating
in Enron&#146;s debt offerings, making disguised loans to Enron and participating in
transactions involving Enron&#146;s SPEs, which were used to avoid recognizing
losses.&#160; Plaintiffs allege that through
the performance of these services, defendants gained knowledge of Enron&#146;s
inflated values but failed to disclose that information.&#160; The </font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">14</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p align="center" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">complaints allege
violations of the Iowa Securities Act and claims for fraud and deceit and for
civil conspiracy.&#160; </font><font style="layout-grid-mode:both;">The Polk County action was removed to federal
court but has been remanded to state court.</font>&#160; The Linn County action has been removed to federal court, and
plaintiffs have moved to remand it back to state court, while defendants have
requested that the action be transferred to the Bankruptcy Court for the
Southern District of New York, where the Enron bankruptcy is proceeding.</p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Also in October
2002, a complaint was filed in Superior Court for Los Angeles County against
LBI, Holdings, and other commercial or investment banks by two Oaktree Capital
Management investment funds.&#160; The
complaint alleges that Enron systematically falsified its financial statements
using improper accounting valuations and false hedges that enabled Enron to
boost its reported earnings.&#160; Plaintiffs
allege that Enron&#146;s bankers, including LBI and Holdings, participated in the
fraudulent scheme by obtaining loan proceeds that Enron falsely characterized
as prepaid commodity trades, falsely concealing the true financial condition of
Enron from rating agencies and institutional investors and creating and using
note offerings by Enron&#146;s SPEs to generate new cash for Enron.&#160; The complaint alleges that defendants knew
and acted on inside information about Enron&#146;s true financial condition in
connection with its offerings of Enron securities, while misrepresenting or
omitting material facts to the public.&#160;
The complaint makes claims under California state law for trading on
inside information, for making false and misleading statements and for unfair
competition by material misstatements or omissions in connection with Enron
securities offerings.&#160; The complaint
seeks compensatory damages, an accounting, restitution and disgorgement of
profits.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2002,
a Second Amended Petition was filed against Andersen in the District Court of
Washington County, Texas, 21st Judicial District, by Jane Bullock and other
purchasers of Enron securities making claims for fraud, negligent misrepresentation
and civil conspiracy in connection with allegedly materially misleading public
statements concerning Enron&#146;s financial condition.&#160; In January 2003, Andersen filed a Third-Party Petition against
LBI, Holdings and other commercial or investment banks.&#160; The Third Party Petition seeks assessment of
proportionate liability and contribution from LBI and Holdings and the other
third-party defendants.&#160; The Third Party
Petition alleges that the third-party defendants were involved in creating,
structuring, using and managing Enron&#146;s SPEs, misrepresented or failed to
disclose information regarding the SPEs, made public statements about Enron,
financially assisted Enron, assisted Enron in raising money, invested in the
SPEs and engaged in transactions involving Enron&#146;s assets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;letter-spacing:0pt;">First Alliance Mortgage Company Matters</font></i></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 1999 and
the first quarter of 2000, Lehman Commercial Paper, Inc. (&#147;LCPI&#148;) provided a
warehouse line of credit to First Alliance Mortgage Company (&#147;FAMCO&#148;), and LBI
underwrote the securitizations of mortgages originated by FAMCO.&#160; Prior to 1999, LCPI had provided a $25
million back-up warehouse line to FAMCO for an 18-month period, and LBI had
co-managed four securitizations, one each quarter, both of which engagements
ended at the conclusion of the third quarter of 1997.&#160; In March 2000, FAMCO filed for protection from its creditors
under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.&#160; In August 2001, a purported adversary class
action (the &#147;Class Action&#148;) was filed in the United States Bankruptcy Court for
the Central District of California (the &#147;Bankruptcy Court&#148;), allegedly on
behalf of a class of FAMCO borrowers seeking equitable subordination of LPCI&#146;s
(among other creditors&#146;) liens and claims in the Bankruptcy Court.&#160; In October 2001, the complaint was amended
to add LBI as a defendant and to add claims for aiding and abetting alleged
fraudulent lending activities by FAMCO and for unfair competition under the
California Business and Professions Code<i><font style="font-style:italic;">.</font></i>&#160;
In August 2002, a Second Amended Complaint was filed, which added a
claim for punitive damages and extended the class period from May 1, 1996,
until FAMCO&#146;s bankruptcy filing.&#160; The
pending complaint seeks actual and punitive damages, the imposition of a
constructive trust on all proceeds paid or being paid by FAMCO to LCPI and LBI,
disgorgement of profits, and attorneys&#146; fees and costs.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In November 2001,
the Official Joint Borrowers Committee (the &#147;Committee&#148;) initiated an adversary
proceeding, allegedly on behalf of the FAMCO-related debtors, in the Bankruptcy
Court by filing a complaint against LCPI, LBI, Holdings and several individual
officers and directors of FAMCO and its affiliates.&#160; As to the Lehman Brothers defendants, the Committee asserted
bankruptcy claims for avoidance of lien, recovery of property, equitable
subordination and disallowance of claim, and also asserted claims for
declaratory relief and aiding and abetting breach of fiduciary duty.&#160; In December 2001, the Committee amended its
complaint, dropping&#160; Holdings as a defendant
and adding claims for equitable indemnification and contribution, which claims
have subsequently been dismissed.&#160; In </font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p align="center" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">addition to relief under
the Bankruptcy Code, the Committee seeks unspecified compensatory damages.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The United States
Court for the Central District of California (the &#147;California District Court&#148;)
withdrew the reference to the Bankruptcy Court in both of these cases and in
February 2002 consolidated them before the California District Court.&#160; In November 2002, the California District
Court entered an order defining the class in the Class Action as &#147;all persons
who acquired mortgage loans from First Alliance from May 1, 1996 through March
31, 2000, which were used as collateral for First Alliance&#146;s warehouse credit
line with Lehman Commercial Paper Inc. or were securitized in transactions
underwritten by Lehman Brothers Inc.&#148;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In February 2003,
the California District Court issued an Order granting Lehman&#146;s motion for
summary judgment on the California Business and Professions Code claims and
granting Lehman&#146;s motion for partial summary judgment on the claims prior to
1999 and dismissing those claims. Trial began on February 18, 2003.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-style:italic;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Separately,
LBI has had discussions with the Florida Attorney General&#146;s office about that
office&#146;s investigation of LBI regarding LBI&#146;s role in connection with First
Alliance.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Actions Regarding Frank Gruttadauria</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">LBI discovered in January
2002 that Frank Gruttadauria, the former branch manager of LBI&#146;s Cleveland
office, which was acquired in October 2000 from SG Cowen Securities Corporation
(&#145;&#145;SG Cowen&#146;&#146;) as part of the purchase by LBI of certain accounts and related
assets belonging to SG Cowen&#146;s private client group, had apparently been
involved in creating false account statements for clients of that office and
may have caused unauthorized transfers of funds from client accounts. This
conduct allegedly took place for a number of years and began well prior to the
acquisition of this office by LBI. Under the terms of the purchase agreement,
SG Cowen retained liability for activities arising out of the conduct or
operation of the business while owned by SG Cowen.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To date, the following
cases have been filed against Lehman Brothers and SG:&#160; eight cases in the United States District Court for the Northern
District of Ohio, six cases in the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois, one case in the United States District Court for
the Southern District of California, and one case in the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin.&#160;
One of the cases pending in the United States District Court for the
Northern District of Illinois has been stayed pending arbitration before the
NASD by agreement of the parties.&#160; Six
arbitrations have been filed including four before the NYSE, the previously
referenced matter before the NASD, and one additional matter before the
NASD.&#160; Four of the foregoing matters,
the case pending in United States District Court for the Southern District of
California, two of the cases pending in the United States District Court for
the Northern District of Illinois, and one of the cases filed before the NYSE,
have been settled.&#160; Generally speaking,
the remaining complaints, amended complaints and statements of claim allege
violations of federal securities laws, violations of state and Blue Sky laws,
civil conspiracy, and common law claims for fraud, promissory estoppel,
negligent and reckless failure to supervise and breach of fiduciary duty.&#160; On the whole, plaintiffs seek compensatory
and punitive damages, pre- and post-judgment interest, attorneys&#146; fees and
costs, an accounting, and in some instances, treble damages.&#160; Each case still pending in federal court is
or will be subject to a motion to stay pending arbitration based on plaintiffs&#146;
contractual agreement to arbitrate their claims against defendants, and eight
of the federal court matters are currently subject to appeals to the United
States Court of Appeals as a result of the district courts&#146; denial of motions
to stay pending arbitration.&#160; One of the
NYSE arbitrations is scheduled to go to a hearing in May of 2003, and one of
the NASD arbitrations is scheduled to go to a hearing in July of 2003.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">LBI received and
responded to requests for information, documents and/or testimony related to
the Gruttadauria matter from the NYSE, the SEC, the Division of Securities of
the Department of Commerce of the State of Ohio (&#147;Ohio Securities Division&#148;)
and the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Financial Services,
Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations.&#160;
LBI is in discussions with the NYSE, the SEC and the Ohio Securities
Division to resolve any regulatory concerns in this matter.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='16',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p align="center" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">IPO Allocation Cases</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-style:italic;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">LBI was named as a defendant in approximately 192 purported
securities class actions that were filed between March and December 2001 in the
New York District Court. The actions, which allege improper IPO allocation
practices, have been brought by persons who, either directly or in the
aftermarket, purchased IPO securities during the period between March 1997 and
December 2000. The plaintiffs allege that Lehman and other IPO underwriters
required persons receiving allocations of IPO shares to pay excessive
commissions on unrelated trades and to purchase shares in the aftermarket at
specified escalating prices. The plaintiffs, who seek unspecified compensatory
damages, claim that these alleged practices violated various provisions of the
federal securities laws, specifically, sections 11, 12(a)(2) and 15 of the
Securities Act, section 10(b) of the Exchange Act, Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and
section 20(a) of the Exchange Act. The 192 actions in which LBI was named a
defendant have been consolidated into 83 cases, each involving a distinct
offering. Those 83 consolidated cases, and approximately 240 others in which
LBI is not named as a defendant, have been coordinated for pretrial purposes
before a single judge.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 2002, a
separate consolidated class action, entitled <i><font style="font-style:italic;">In
re Initial Public Offering Antitrust Litigatio</font></i>n, was filed against
LBI, among other underwriters, alleging violations of federal and state
antitrust laws. The complaint alleges that the underwriter defendants conspired
to require customers who wanted IPO allocations to pay back to the underwriters
a percentage of their IPO profits in the form of commissions on unrelated
trades, to purchase other, less attractive securities and to buy shares in the
aftermarket at predetermined escalating prices. Originally filed as twelve
separate class actions in three different courts, the consolidated antitrust
action is now pending before a single judge&#151;different from the one hearing the
securities cases&#151;in the New York District Court. The antitrust plaintiffs seek
unspecified treble damages.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">In April 2002, a suit was filed in
Delaware Chancery Court by Breakaway Solutions Inc. (&#147;Breakaway&#148;), which names
LBI and two other underwriters as defendants.&#160;
The complaint purports to be brought on behalf of a class of issuers who
issued securities in initial public offerings (&#147;IPOs&#148;) through at least one of
the defendants during the period of January 1998 through October 2000 and whose
securities increased in value 15% or more above the original price within 30
days after the IPO.&#160; It alleges that
defendants underpriced IPO securities and allocated those underpriced
securities to certain favored customers in return for alleged arrangements with
the customers for increased commissions on other transactions and alleged
tie-in arrangements.&#160; The complaint
asserts claims for breaches of contract, of the implied covenant of good faith
and fair dealing and of fiduciary duty, and for indemnification or contribution
and unjust enrichment or restitution.&#160;
Breakaway seeks, among other relief, certification of a class, a
permanent injunction preventing defendants from engaging in the alleged
practices, an accounting of all defendants&#146; commissions, profits and
compensation in connection with the IPOs, declarations requiring defendants to
indemnify Breakaway in the pending consolidated IPO securities class actions
and determining that Breakaway has no indemnification obligation to defendants
in those actions, and compensatory damages.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">IPO Fee Litigation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Harold
Gillet, et al. v. Goldman Sachs &amp; Co., et al.; Yakov Prager, et al. v.
Goldman, Sachs &amp; Co., et al.; David Holzman, et al. v. Goldman, Sachs &amp;
Co., et al.&#160; </font></i>Beginning
in November 1998, four purported class actions were filed in the New York
District Court against in excess of 25 underwriters of initial public offering
(&#145;&#145;IPO&#146;&#146;) securities, including LBI. Plaintiffs, alleged purchasers of
securities issued in certain IPOs, seek compensatory and injunctive relief for
alleged violations of the antitrust laws based on the theory that the
defendants fixed and maintained fees for underwriting certain IPO securities at
supra-competitive levels. By memorandum and order in February 2001 (the
&#145;&#145;Order&#146;&#146;), the New York District Court granted defendants&#146; motion to dismiss
the Consolidated Amended Complaint, concluding that the purchaser plaintiffs
lacked standing under the antitrust laws to assert the claims. On appeal, the
U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reversed and remanded the case to
the New York District Court for further proceedings, including potential
dismissal of the claims based on additional arguments raised in the motion to
dismiss.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">In Re
Issuer Plaintiff Initial Public Offering Fee Antitrust Litigation. </font></i>&#160;By order dated April 10, 2001, the New York
District Court consolidated four actions pending before the court brought by
bankrupt issuers of IPO securities </p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">17</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font></b>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">against more than 20 underwriter defendants (including
LBI). In July 2001, the plaintiffs filed a consolidated class action complaint
seeking unspecified compensatory damages and injunctive relief for alleged
violations of the antitrust laws based on the theory that the defendant
underwriters fixed and maintained fees for underwriting certain IPO securities
at supra-competitive levels. CHS Electronics and MDCM Holdings, two of the four
original plaintiffs, subsequently withdrew their claims.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Island Venture Corporation, et al.
v. Lehman Brothers Inc. and Lehman Brothers Securities Asia, Ltd.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On February 9, 2001,
Island Venture Corporation, Continental Resources Corporation, Recola
Investment Corporation, Grand Concord Corporation and Goodwell Industrial
Corporation filed a First Amended Complaint in the United States District Court
for the District of New Jersey against LBI and Lehman Brothers Securities Asia,
Ltd. In July 2001, plaintiffs filed a Second Amended Complaint. The complaint
arises in connection with the plaintiffs&#146; purchase of various promissory notes
issued by Indonesian companies in 1997 and upon which the issuers have
defaulted. It also asserts claims relating to an alleged unauthorized
liquidation for $8.5 million of a $10 million Asia Investment Grade Default
Note (&#145;&#145;Basket Note&#146;&#146;) issued by Lehman Brothers Holdings PLC. The complaint
seeks rescission and damages under various common law theories of mutual
mistake, breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, negligent
misrepresentation and constructive fraud, as well as asserting claims under
Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act. The plaintiffs seek to recover
damages of approximately $60 million on all the notes they purchased and the
difference between the liquidation price and the face value of the Basket Note
plus lost interest payments.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h3 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:normal;letter-spacing:0pt;">In re Metricom Securities Litigation</font></i></b></h3>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In August 2002, a First
Amended Consolidated Class Action Complaint for Violation of the Securities Act
of 1933 and the Exchange Act of 1934, Corrected Copy, was filed in the United
States District Court for the Northern District of California captioned <i><font style="font-style:italic;">In re Metricom Securities Litigation</font></i>.&#160; The action is brought on behalf of a
purported class of investors who purchased the common stock of Metricom, Inc.,
during the period from June 21, 1999, to July 2, 2001. Plaintiffs name various
officers, directors and selling shareholders of Metricom, along with LBI and
the four other co-managing underwriters of an offering of Metricom common stock
on February 3, 2000. Prior to the commencement of this action, Metricom filed
for protection under the federal bankruptcy code. The February 2000 offering
raised approximately $500 million.&#160;
Against the underwriters, plaintiffs allege violations of Sections 11
and 12(2) of the Securities Act and of Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act. The
complaint alleges that the prospectus and registration statement for the
offering failed to disclose material facts concerning, among other things,
Metricom&#146;s flawed business plan and marketing strategy. The complaint seeks
class action status, damages and &#145;&#145;statutory compensation,&#148; and attorneys&#146; fees
and other costs.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">WorldCom Bondholders Litigation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">LBI and other
underwriters of WorldCom, Inc., bonds issued in several offerings in each of
1997, 1998, 2000 and 2001 have been named as defendants in certain lawsuits
alleging that the offering materials were false and misleading.&#160; LBI underwrote $915 million principal amount
of bonds in the 1998 offerings and $375 million principal amount of bonds in
the 2000 offerings.&#160; (LBI did not
participate in the 1997 and 2001 offerings.)&#160;
With respect to LBI, a purported class action was filed in July 2002 in
the New York District Court.&#160; On October
11, 2002, the complaint was superceded by the filing of a consolidated putative
class action complaint in the New York District Court, entitled <i><font style="font-style:italic;">In re WorldCom, Inc. Securities Litigation</font></i>.&#160; This action alleges violations by the
underwriters of the federal securities law, including Sections 11 and 12 of the
Securities Act, in connection with May 2000 and May 2001 bond offerings, and is
brought on behalf of purchasers and acquirers of bonds issued in or traceable
to these offerings.&#160; In addition to the
above purported class action, a number of individual actions have been filed in
connection with some or all of these WorldCom bond offerings.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A lawsuit was filed in
October 2002 in the Supreme Court of the State of New York, New York County, by
municipal pension funds that allegedly purchased WorldCom common stock and $383
million principal amount of WorldCom notes, an unspecified amount of which are alleged
to be traceable to the 2000 public offerings.&#160;
The complaint alleges violations of Section 11 of the Securities Act,
along with common law claims, against LBI and </font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font></b>

<p align="center" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Holdings.&#160; Plaintiffs seek, among other things,
unspecified compensatory and punitive damages.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A suit was filed in
November 2002 in the Washington Superior Court, Kings County, by a state
pension fund that allegedly purchased approximately $162 million principal
amount of WorldCom notes issued in the 1998, 2000 and 2001 public offerings.
The complaint alleges violations of Section 11 of the Securities Act by LBI and
Holdings.&#160; Plaintiff seeks unspecified
compensatory damages, among other things.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Three other lawsuits were
filed in November 2002 and January 2003 in the Superior Court of California,
Los Angeles County, by county, municipal and private pension and retirement
funds that allegedly purchased, respectively, approximately $157 million, $102
million and $135 million principal amount of WorldCom notes issued in the 1998,
2000 and 2001 public offerings and a December 2000 private offering.&#160; The complaints allege violations of Section
11 of the Securities Act by LBI and Holdings.&#160;
Plaintiffs seek rescission or unspecified compensatory damages, among
other things.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Two suits were filed in
December 2002 in the Wisconsin Circuit Court, Dane County, and in the State of
Minnesota District Court, Second Judicial District, by state and municipal
pension funds, which allegedly purchased a total of approximately $133 million
and $161 million, respectively, of WorldCom notes issued in the 1998, 2000 and
2001 public offerings. The complaint alleges violations of Section 11 of the
Securities Act by LBI and Holdings.&#160;
Plaintiffs seek rescission or unspecified compensatory damages, among
other things.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A</font><font style="layout-grid-mode:both;"> lawsuit was filed in January 2003 in the
Chancery Court of Davidson County in Tennessee on behalf of the Tennessee
Consolidated Retirement System, which allegedly purchased $60 million principal
amount of WorldCom notes issued in the 1998 and 2000 offerings (as well as $102
million in the 2001 offerings in which Lehman did not participate).&#160; The complaint alleges violations of Section
11 of the Securities Act against LBI and Holdings and seeks unspecified
compensatory damages, among other things.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">In addition, actions have been
filed in federal court in Mississippi by a bank and trust company and in state
courts in Ohio and Montana by a state or union pension funds; each, insofar as
LBI is concerned, allege violations of disclosure requirements and assert
damages of less than $15 million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Each of these individual actions, with the exception
of the actions filed in January 2003, has been removed to federal court and
each has been, or is expected to be, transferred by the Judicial Panel on
Multidistrict Litigation to the New York District Court for consolidated
pre-trial proceedings with the class action pending in the New York District
Court.&#160; A motion to remand these actions
to state court is pending.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Most of these actions
also name as defendants certain of WorldCom&#146;s present or former officers and/or
directors and/or WorldCom&#146;s outside accounting firm.&#160; On July 21, 2002, WorldCom, Inc. filed for protection under the
U.S. bankruptcy laws.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt .5in;text-indent:.5in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item4_SubmissionOfMattersToAVote"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 4. SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS</font></b></a></h5>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p>


<div style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

</font></b>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><a name="PartIi"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART
II</font></b></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-align:left;text-indent:-.75in;"><a name="Item5_MarketForRegistrantsCommonE"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 5.</font></b></a><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font style="letter-spacing:0pt;">MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON EQUITY AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The approximate
number of holders of record of the Registrant&#146;s Common Stock was </font><font style="layout-grid-mode:both;">22,700</font> at February&nbsp;14, 2003.
Information concerning the market for the Registrant&#146;s common equity, dividends
and related stockholder matters is set forth under the captions &#147;Selected
Financial Data&#148; and &#147;Other Stockholder Information&#148; in the 2002 Annual Report,
and is incorporated herein by reference.</p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item6_SelectedFinancialData"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 6.  SELECTED FINANCIAL DATA</font></b></a></h5>

<p align="left" style="line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The information
under the captions &#147;Selected Financial Data&#148; and &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and
Analysis&#151;Certain Factors Affecting Results of Operations&#148; contained in the 2002
Annual Report and the information under &#147;Item 1&#151;Business&#151;Forward-Looking
Statements&#148; in this Report is incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;text-align:left;text-indent:-.75in;"><a name="Item7_ManagementsDiscussionAndAna"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 7. </font></b></a><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&#160; </font><font style="letter-spacing:0pt;">MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF
OPERATIONS</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt 49.5pt;text-indent:-49.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Management&#146;s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations is set
forth under the caption &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis&#148; in the 2002
Annual Report. Such information is incorporated herein by reference and should
be read in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements and the Notes
thereto contained in the 2002 Annual Report.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item7a_QuantitativeAndQualitativeDi"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 7A.&#160;&#160; QUANTITATIVE AND
QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK</font></b></a></h5>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The information
under the caption &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis&#151;Risk Management&#148; in the
2002 Annual Report is incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item8_FinancialStatementsAndSupple"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 8.  FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND
SUPPLEMENTARY DATA</font></b></a></h5>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Consolidated
Financial Statements of the Registrant and its Subsidiaries together with the
Notes thereto and the Report of Independent Auditors thereon required by this
Item are contained in the 2002 Annual Report and are incorporated herein by
reference.&#160;&#160; Condensed unconsolidated
financial information of Holdings and notes thereto are set forth in Schedule I
beginning on Page F-2 of this Report and are incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt .75in;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;text-indent:-.75in;"><a name="Item9_ChangesInAndDisagreementsWi"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 9. </font></b></a><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font style="letter-spacing:0pt;">CHANGES IN AND DISAGREEMENTS WITH ACCOUNTANTS ON
ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE</font></h5>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">None.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">20</font></p>


<div align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='20',FILE='C:\C2\mvangb\7875_9\t_1241333\j7875_10k.htm',USER='mvangb',CD='Feb 28 15:26 2003' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font></b>

<p align="center" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><a name="PartIii"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART
III</font></b></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item10_DirectorsAndExecutiveOffice"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 10. &#160; DIRECTORS AND EXECUTIVE
OFFICERS OF THE REGISTRANT</font></b></a></h5>

<p align="left" style="line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">Information relating to Directors
of the Registrant is set forth under the captions &#147;Nominees for Election as
Class&nbsp;III Directors to Serve until the 2006 Annual Meeting of
Stockholders,&#148; &#147;Class&nbsp;I Directors Whose Terms Continue until the 2005
Annual Meeting of Stockholders&#148; and &#147;Class&nbsp;II Directors Whose Terms
Continue until the 2004 Annual Meeting of Stockholders&#148; in the Proxy Statement,
and information relating to Executive Officers of the Registrant is set forth
under the caption &#147;Executive Officers of the Company&#148; in the Proxy Statement,
and is incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item11_ExecutiveCompensation"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 11.&#160;&#160; EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION</font></b></a></h5>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Information
relating to executive compensation is set forth under the captions
&#147;Compensation of Directors&#148;, &#147;Compensation and Benefits Committee Interlocks
and Insider Participation,&#148; &#147;Compensation of Executive Officers,&#148; &#147;Pension
Benefits&#148; and &#147;Employment Contracts, Termination of Employment and Change in
Control Arrangements&#148; in the Proxy Statement and is incorporated herein by
reference.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item12_SecurityOwnershipOfCertain"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 12. &#160; SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF
CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT</font></b></a></h5>

<p align="left" style="line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Information
relating to security ownership of certain beneficial owners and management is
set forth under the captions &#147;Security Ownership of Principal Stockholders&#148; and
&#147;Security Ownership of Directors and Executive Officers&#148; in the Proxy Statement
and is incorporated herein by reference.&#160;&#160;
Information relating to securities
of the Registrant authorized for issuance under equity compensation plans
is set forth under the caption &#147;Equity Compensation Plan Information&#148; in the
Proxy Statement and is incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item13_CertainRelationshipsAndRela"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 13. &#160; CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND
RELATED TRANSACTIONS</font></b></a></h5>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Information
relating to certain relationships and related transactions is set forth under
the captions &#147;Certain Transactions and Agreements with Directors and Executive
Officers&#148; and &#147;Certain Transactions and Agreements with American Express and
Subsidiaries&#148; in the Proxy Statement and is incorporated herein by reference.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><a name="Item14_ControlsAndProcedures"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM 14.&#160;&#160; CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</font></b></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and
the Chief Financial Officer of Holdings (its </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">principal executive officer and principal financial
officer, respectively) </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">have concluded, based on their evaluation as of a
date within 90 days prior to the date of the filing of this Report, that the
Company&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures are effective </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">to ensure that information required to be
disclosed by Holdings in the reports filed or submitted by it under the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, is recorded, processed, summarized
and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC&#146;s rules and forms,
and include controls and procedures designed to ensure that information
required to be disclosed by Holdings in such reports is accumulated and
communicated to the Company&#146;s management, including </font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">the Chairman and Chief
Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer of Holdings,</font><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;"> as appropriate to allow timely decisions
regarding required disclosure.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">There
were no significant changes in the Company&#146;s internal controls or in other
factors that could significantly affect these controls subsequent to the date
of such evaluation.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">21</font></p>


<div align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;font-weight:bold;">

<hr size="2" width="100%" noshade color="gray" align="left">

</font></b></div>

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
</font>

<p align="center" style="font-size:9.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;">&nbsp;</p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:center;"><a name="PartIv"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART
IV</font></b></a></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<h5 align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:left;"><a name="Item15_"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">ITEM

<h2 style="font-weight:bold;letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:center;"><a name="Signatures"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">SIGNATURES</font></b></a></h2>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;text-indent:.25in;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:0pt;">Pursuant to the requirements of
Section&nbsp;13 or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, the Registrant
has duly caused this Annual Report to be signed on its behalf by the
undersigned, thereunto duly authorized.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0in 0in .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="left" style="line-height:normal;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

Securities Exchange Act of 1934, this Report has been signed below by the
following persons on behalf of the Registrant and in the capacities and on the
dates indicated.</font></p>

  <p style="font-size:1.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>
  </td>
  <td width="35%" valign="top" style="padding:0in 0in 0in 0in;width:35.3%;">
  <p style="font-size:1.0pt;margin:0in 0in .0001pt;">&nbsp;</p>
  </td>
